articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
When working with CSS Grid, the first thing to do is to set display: grid on the element that we want to be become a grid container. Then we explicitly define the grid using a combination of grid-template-columns, grid-template-rows…
Exploring CSS Grid’s Implicit Grid and Auto-Placement Powers originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Exploring CSS Grid’s Implicit Grid and Auto-Placement Powers

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Chris calls scroll shadows one his favorite CSS-Tricks of all time. Lea Verou popularized the pure CSS approach using four layered background gradients with some clever background-attachment magic. The result is a slick scrolling interaction that gives users a hint …
Scroll Shadows? Pure CSS Parallax? Game Back On. originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Scroll Shadows? Pure CSS Parallax? Game Back On.

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
It’s no secret that MDN rolled out a new design back in March. It’s gorgeous! And there are some sweet CSS-y gems in it that are fun to look at. One of those gems is how card components handle truncated …
Recreating MDN’s Truncated Text Effect originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Recreating MDN’s Truncated Text Effect

articles.author: Obumuneme Nwabude
articles.description:
URL Shorteners are tools we use to make links shorter than they actually are. With a URL Shortener, you can transform a long link (maybe for a registration form or article) into a shorter version.
Behind the scenes, the long …
Why I Chose Angular to Build a URL Shortener originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Why I Chose Angular to Build a URL Shortener

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
It’s not everyday that HTML headings are the topic de jour, but my folder of saved links is accumulating articles about the recently merged removal of the document outline algorithm in the WHATWG Living Standard.
First off, you should know …
Roundup of Recent Document Outline Chatter originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Roundup of Recent Document Outline Chatter

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Michelle Barker with my favorite sorta blog post: short, practical, and leaves you with a valuable nugget for your time. Here, she gets into logical property shorthands in CSS, particularly those that set lengths just on a single axis, …
Logical Properties for Useful Shorthands originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Logical Properties for Useful Shorthands

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.title: How stroke-dasharray Patterns Work

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
I think it’s super timely that Jim Nielsen wrote about his office space the other day. My family recently re-rooted in Colorado and I was up late last night setting up my desk and everything around it. So late, in …
Office Spaces originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Office Spaces

articles.author: Blessing Ene Anyebe
articles.description:
Hooks are reusable functions. They allow you to use state and other features (e.g. lifecycle methods and so on) without writing a class. Hook functions let us “hook into” the React state lifecycle using functional components, allowing us to manipulate …
React Hooks: The Deep Cuts originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: React Hooks: The Deep Cuts

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
Our dear friend Robin has a new essay called In Praise of Shadows. Now, before you hop over there looking for nuggets on CSS box shadows, text shadows, and shadow filters… this is not that. It’s an essay …
In Praise of Shadows originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: In Praise of Shadows

articles.author: Eluda
articles.description:
HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, PHP, C++, Dart — there are so many programming languages out there and you may even be totally fluent in several of them! But as we aim to write more and better code, the way we …
Technical Writing for Developers originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Technical Writing for Developers

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ruslan Yevych)
articles.description: If you like math and CSS, you’ll love this one. We don’t need to use media queries to change the values of some CSS properties — *font-size*, *padding*, *margin* etc. — depending on the viewport width, with the CSS `clamp` function. But: we still need to use media queries for changing colors, borders, shadows and other CSS styles.
articles.title: Fluid Sizing Instead Of Multiple Media Queries?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you need a little inspiration boost? Well, then our new batch of desktop wallpapers is for you. Designed by artists and designers from across the globe, they come in versions with and without a calendar for August 2022.
articles.title: Memories Of August (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Noam Rosenthal)
articles.description: Testing is not just about tools and processes. It’s about architecture. In this article, Noam Rosenthal will share his experience on how to organize testing and find the right balance between front-end and subsystems and between different strategies.
articles.title: Testable Frontend: The Good, The Bad And The Flaky

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Olushuyi Olutimilehin)
articles.description:
In this article, Olushuyi explores a mental model that helps you decide between the `` and `
` elements when writing documents. You will explore how grouping content affects accessibility and how you can make it all count for users.
articles.title: <article> vs. <section>: How To Choose The Right One

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: In this article, Luis Ouriach helps to develop your own guiding principles to become a better designer so that you can walk into the design critique meetings with more confidence and really deliver the best representation of your ideas.
articles.title: Overcoming Imposter Syndrome By Developing Your Own Guiding Principles

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jarijn Nijkamp)
articles.description: Now that some time has passed since the team returned from SmashingConf San Francisco, we’ve had time to think about the event and wrap up some of the things we all learned.
articles.title: Looking Back At SmashingConf SF 2022

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Louis Lazaris)
articles.description: Optimizing the size of images can have a bigger impact on performance than all other areas combined. In this article, Louis Lazaris covers different tools available for reducing the size of images.
articles.title: Powerful Image Optimization Tools

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eric Burel)
articles.description: “Segmented Rendering” is a new pattern and it will change the Jamstack game forever. Let’s try to push the boundaries of static rendering and learn how to apply it to personalized content.
articles.title: A New Pattern For The Jamstack: Segmented Rendering

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Scott Himmer)
articles.description: In this article, Scott Himmer will go over some areas where you might find the design and engineering conflicts manifesting, what some of the contributing factors are, and strategies to work through the challenges.
articles.title: Resolving Conflicts Between Designers And Engineers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Raphael Amoedo)
articles.description: Using only Docker to build and run applications and commands removes the need for previous knowledge in some tool or programming language. Also, it avoids the necessity to install new modules and dependencies directly to the system, which makes development machine-independent.
articles.title: Using Nothing But Docker For Projects

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we ask what qualities are required to introduce change in large organizations, how to convince management to do the right thing, and how to ship a billion-dollar idea. Vitaly talks to expert Paul Boag to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 49 With Paul Boag: How Do You Ship A Billion-Dollar Idea?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: In this article, Zara Cooper will examine some of the features of the Kendo UI for Angular Data Grid in comparison to those offered by the Angular Material Table.
articles.title: Kendo UI For Angular Data Grid And Angular Material: Have Your Cake And Eat It Too

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani)
articles.description: Let’s talk about Remix, the framework to create JavaScript projects using server-side rendering. Let’s go through its main features and concepts and see the similarities and differences with Next.js.
articles.title: A Look At Remix And The Differences With Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lyndon Cerejo)
articles.description: As a designer, you may be tasked with figuring out how your company should approach the metaverse or thinking about designing for the metaverse. In this article, Lyndon Cerejo will discuss a few steps he recommends before diving headfirst into any design for the metaverse.
articles.title: A Five-Step Approach To The Metaverse

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kent Eisenhuth & Kai Chang)
articles.description: In this article, we will explore how an accessibility-first approach can lead you down the path of creating a better visual design for charts. Throughout the article, you’ll learn to use the Web Content Accessibility Standards and how this approach leadd to an unexpected yet better outcome for everyone.
articles.title: An Accessibility-First Approach To Chart Visual Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: In this [series of articles](/category/design-patterns/), we highlight design patterns and techniques to design better interfaces. You can find more examples in [“Smart Interface Design Patterns”](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com/), a 7h-video course with 100s of hand-picked examples, curated by Vitaly.
articles.title: Designing A Perfect Pricing Page UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: In this tutorial, Zara Cooper explains how to use Strapi’s Internationalization feature to create content in multiple languages. You’ll also learn how to create a Hugo site that consumes localized content from Strapi.
articles.title: How To Build A Localized Website With Hugo And Strapi

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (John Scott Bowie)
articles.description: In this article, John Scott Bowie shares the story of 40 years of attempts to advance corporate UX maturity that — after numerous initiatives with marginal results — culminated in a breakthrough project that accelerated a company’s UX maturity from “Emergent” to “User-Driven” in less than a year.
articles.title: Accelerating UX Maturity With A Breakthrough Project

articles.author: Matthes Bär
articles.description: In this tutorial, you'll learn how to set up dynamic routing in Next.js. You'll also learn about pre-rendering and why it's important. 🔐 Here's what we'll cover:  * You'll get to know getStaticPaths(), one of the core principles of Next.js.  * You'll improve your general Next.js knowledge and
articles.title: Routing in Next.js – How to Set Up Dynamic Routing with Pre-Rendering in Next

articles.author: Joel Olawanle
articles.description: Sometimes you might have an array of words where you want to sort each word alphabetically (from a-z). Or you might have an array of objects containing user information including names, for example, where you want to sort the users by their names. We can do this in JavaScript by
articles.title: Sort Alphabetically in JavaScript – How to Order by Name in JS

articles.author: Sophia Iroegbu
articles.description: Choosing a tech career can be tricky because there are many possible paths to choose from. There's Web Development, Machine Learning, Data Science, DevOps, and many more. But the good news is you don't necessarily have to be a developer to be in the world of tech. This article is
articles.title: How to Choose a Tech Career in 2022 – A Career Changer's Guide

articles.title: How to Authenticate a User with Face Recognition in React.js

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: When collaborating with other developers using Git, you might encounter the  error: failed to push some refs to [remote repo] error. This error mainly occurs when you attempt to push your local changes to GitHub while the local repository (repo) has not yet been updated with any changes made
articles.title: Error: failed to push some refs to – How to Fix in Git

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: When working with a JavaScript program, you might need to replace a character or word with another one. Specifically, you may need to replace not just one but all occurrences of that character or word with something else. There are a few ways you can achieve this with JavaScript. One
articles.title: JavaScript replaceAll() – Replace All Instances of a String in JS

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: In Python, a dictionary is one of the core data structures. It is a sequence of key-value pairs separated by commas and surrounded by curly braces. If you’re familiar with JavaScript, Python dictionaries are like JavaScript objects. Python provides more than 10 methods for working with dictionaries. In this article,
articles.title: Python Dictionary Methods – Dictionaries in Python

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: JavaScript can be used to develop a bunch of different types of games. And games created with JavaScript can run on almost any device with a web browser. We just published a 10-hour JavaScript game development course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel. You will learn to make 2D games with
articles.title: Learn Game Development with JavaScript

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: When working with JavaScript and the Document Object Model (DOM), you might want your script to run only when the DOM has loaded.  You can do this using the $(document).ready() method in jQuery, or the  DOMContentLoaded event in vanilla JavaScript. In this article, you'll learn how to make
articles.title: JavaScript document.ready() – Document Ready JS and jQuery Example

articles.author: Stephen Sanwo
articles.description: In order to build a working full-stack application, there are so many moving parts to think about. And you'll need to make many decisions that will be critical to the success of your app. For example, what language will you use and what platform will you deploy on? Are you
articles.title: The AI Chatbot Handbook – How to Build an AI Chatbot with Redis, Python, and GPT
